The vector dot product The work done by a force $\vtr {f}$ f f in moving along $\vtr {d}$ d d is $W = fd\cos \theta $ W = fd , see figure 1 (c): the distance actually moved, along the direction of the force along the direction of the force , is $d\cos \theta $ d (i.e. the projection of $\vtr {d}$ d d onto $\vtr {f}$ f f ). The work done, is this distance times the magnitude of the force.
Work is the scalar (dot) product of the two vectors: $W = \vtr {f} \cdot \vtr {d} = fd\cos \theta $ W = f f d d = fd . The dot product of perpendicular vectors is zero. Thus $\vtr {i} \cdot \vtr {j} = \vtr {j} \cdot \vtr {k} = \vtr {k} \cdot \vtr {i} = 0$ i i j j = j j k k = k k i i = 0 .
